The rapid growth of global urbanization and industrialization has aggravated environmental pollution and energy consumption. As a clean and renewable energy source, hydrogen has garnered significant attention for its potential in addressing these challenges. Note that MXenes, composed of transition metal carbides, nitrides or carbonitrides, are two-dimensional (2D) materials that have become attractive candidates for hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) process due to the high electrical conductivity, large surface area, excellent chemical stability and tunable surface chemical properties. This review provides a comprehensive overview of MXene based electrocatalysts for the HER, including various synthesis methods (chemical etching, physical etching, exfoliation and intercalation) and their effects on morphology, composition and electrochemical properties. The review further explores performance enhancement strategies including surface functionalization, doping engineering and heterostructure construction. Furthermore, it highlights current challenges and future prospects in MXene synthesis and applications in HER, while proposing a development framework for high-performance MXene based electrocatalysts in clean energy generation and energy conversion/storage systems. Graphical Abstract Keywords MXenes Synthesis Electrocatalysts Hydrogen evolution reaction Clean energy Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction The increasing global demand for energy has led to the widespread use of non-renewable resources such as fossil fuels, coal and natural gas, resulting in significant environmental pollution and sustainability challenges [1]. It is projected that by 2035, the energy demand be double due to the economic growth of both developed and emerging countries. It is therefore particularly important to seek a potential energy source that can reduce dependence on fossil fuels and minimize harmful emissions [2]. To address related energy issues, a range of energy storage technologies, such as fuel cells [3], batteries [4] and supercapacitors [5] have emerged. The stability, cost and durability of electrode materials in these devices have a crucial impact on the performance, making the development of electrode materials that meet future energy demands a research priority [6]. Researchers have taken a keen interest in the process of hydrogen (H2) generation from water splitting through electrolysis and energy conversion in fuel cells [7]. Hydrogen energy, as a clean energy source, is receiving more attention from countries around the world due to its zero pollution, high energy density (120–142 MJ/kg), no greenhouse gas emissions and a broad range of applications [8,9]. In addition, the drive for applications in oil refining, ammonia (NH3) production, steel manufacturing and other industrial sectors has led to a significant increase in the demand for H2 production. Meanwhile, H2 is being explored as a viable alternative to coal and natural gas to reduce the annual 830 million tons of CO2 emissions [10]. Therefore, developing and scaling up high-efficiency devices to produce green H2 has become crucial [7]. Currently, there are a variety of hydrogen production pathways with distinct levels of technological maturity and carbon intensity. The most prevalent methods for hydrogen generation involve steam methane reforming or gasification from fossil fuels [11,12]. However, the conventional steam methane reforming process is a significant source of carbon dioxide emissions, which is a primary sponsor of global warming and the greenhouse effect. In order to reduce the costs associated with hydrogen production and minimize environmental pollution, researchers have developed some alternative methods, including photobiological water splitting, thermochemical water splitting and photoelectrochemical water splitting [13]. Among these, electrochemical water splitting (EWS) stands out as an economically feasible and environmentally benign approach, capable of generating high-purity hydrogen through the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) [14,15]. Some studies have demonstrated that optimizing catalyst materials can mitigate the thermodynamic barriers associated with the kinetic intermediates of HER, thereby reducing the overpotential and enhancing the electrochemical performance [16]. Since HER is fundamentally based on the adsorption/desorption of hydrogen atoms, the interaction between hydrogen atoms and active sites of HER process is crucial for the performance of catalysts. Although noble metal catalysts such as platinum (Pt) [17], ruthenium (Ru) [18] and rhodium (Rh) [19] exhibit excellent electrochemical performance in HER, the scarcity of the resources and rising costs limit the large-scale application. Consequently, there is a rigorous effort to develop low-cost and sustainable HER electrocatalysts. Currently, a variety of electrocatalytic materials have been developed, including noble-metal-based catalysts [20], transition metal oxides (TMOs) [21], transition metal sulfides (TMSs) [22], TMCs [23], transition metal nitrides (TMNs) [24], metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) [25], transition metal dichalcogenides (TMDs) [26], black phosphorus (BP) [27], layered double hydroxides (LDHs) [28] and carbon materials [29]. Two-dimensional (2D) materials have garnered significant attention due to their unique physical, chemical and electronic properties. 2D materials contain several atomic layers held with weak van der Waals forces, which can be stripped into thinner layers or monolayers of nanosheets, thus leading to a larger surface area and a larger number of catalytically active sites with enhanced electrochemical properties [30,31]. Note that the distinctive band structures of 2D materials modified through doping, functionalization, or heterojunctions, can improve the catalytic activity for specific reactions [32]. However, certain TMDs, such as molybdenum disulfide (MoS2), possess limited intrinsic conductivity, hindering effective charge transfer and consequently reducing HER efficiency [33]. Transition metal nitrides, carbides and/or carbonitrides nanomaterials (MXenes) are novel 2D layered materials that have garnered significant interest among researchers due to their exceptional functionalization capabilities and excitingly high conductivity. Yury Gogotsi et al. [34] synthesized the first MXene by selectively etching the middle aluminum (Al) layer of the Ti3AlC2 MAX phase using hydrofluoric acid (HF) as the etchant. The general molecular formula for the MAX phase is M n+1AX n , where n can vary between 1 and 4; M denotes an early transition metal element; A represents primarily an element from groups IIIA or IVA and X signifies carbon, nitrogen, or a mixture of both elements. The resulting MXenes exhibit unique layered structures where metal atoms are sandwiched between two carbon or nitrogen layers, providing high surface areas and numerous active sites. These MXenes materials have been theoretically or experimentally proven, such as Ti3C2 [34], V2C [35], Mo2C [36], Zr3C2 [37], and (Mo2Ti2)C3 [38]. The unique arrangement, coupled with the material's metallic conductivity, superior mechanical properties and chemical stability, renders MXenes suitable for electrocatalytic applications, particularly for HER [39]. Additionally, the hydrophilicity of MXenes allows them to interact with water molecules and form stable colloidal solutions in water and organic solvents, thus offering unique electronic characteristics and surface chemical environments[40]. In summary, MXenes are considered ideal HER electrocatalysts due to their stability, low cost, unique surface chemistry, well-optimized active centers and efficient charge transfer kinetics [41,42]. This review delivers a detailed classification and summary of the synthesis of MXenes and discusses the strategies for controlling MXenes, offering a comprehensive analysis and critical evaluation of the latest advancements in HER. Systematically reviews various synthesis approaches including chemical etching, intercalation and exfoliation techniques and discusses the effects on the morphology, composition and electrochemical properties of four categories of pristine MXenes, surface-functionalized MXenes, doped-atom MXenes and MXene heterostructures. Subsequently, the catalytic performance of MXenes in HER is presented, focusing on the activity, stability and reaction kinetics, and highlighting the selectivity, efficiency and mechanisms. The overall thematic idea of this review study can be seen in Scheme 1. Finally, the review highlights the challenges in the synthesis methods of MXene based materials and provides a robust framework for the development of MXene based electrocatalytic materials for efficient HER electrocatalysts. 2 Hydrogen evolution reaction Hydrogen is considered a means of balancing energy storage and power grids, serving as a complement to the intermittent nature of renewable energy sources. In recent years, there has been a concerted effort to tackle the challenges in hydrogen production, transportation, storage and distribution, which are in the pursuit of enhancing efficiency and cutting costs. HER occurs at the cathode as the critical half-reaction during the process of water splitting. As mentioned previously, the water electrolysis reaction consists of two half-reactions: HER and the oxygen evolution reaction (OER), which are sensitive to pH levels. In alkaline and neutral environments, the reduction of two water molecules can yield two hydrogen molecules and a hydroxide ion, whereas in acidic conditions, the reduction of two protons results in the formation of a single hydrogen molecule [43]. Thus, in both acidic and alkaline conditions, HER processes at standard temperature and pressure can be described as follows: In alkaline conditions: (1) H2O + e → H* + OH- (Volmer step) (2) H* +H2O + e → H2 + OH- (Heyrovsky step) (3) H* + H* → H2 (Tafel step) In acidic conditions: (4) H+ + e → H* (Volmer step) (5) H+ + e + H* → H2 (Heyrovsky step) (6) H* + H* → H2 (Tafel step) The mechanisms of HER in both alkaline and acidic media are depicted in Fig. 1. The number of absorbed hydrogen atoms (H*), where * represents adsorbed sites on the electrode surface, leads to the division of HER into two main reaction mechanisms: the Heyrovsky and Tafel mechanisms. In the initial stage of the reaction in both media, H₂O or protons on the catalytically active sites are electrochemically oxidized to form H*, where a step commonly referred to as the Volmer reaction. Following the initial step, two possible pathways may exist in the second stage. The Heyrovsky mechanism operates under conditions of low H* surface coverage, where H* receives an additional electron and combines with a water molecule or a proton to produce molecular H2 in alkaline and acidic environments, respectively. Conversely, when H* surface coverage is high, the Tafel mechanism dominates where two H* species can directly form the H2 gas. In addition, the Gibbs free energy for H2 adsorption (ΔG H*) is commonly utilized to evaluate the energy barrier associated with initiating reactions on catalysts. This parameter quantifies the degree of binding strength between H2 species and the surface of the electrocatalyst. The ideal value of ΔG H* during HER processes is close to 0, indicating an equilibrium between adsorption and desorption phenomena. The efficiency of HER catalysts is generally assessed by overpotential, which represents the difference between the actual voltage applied to the electrode and the theoretical voltage required, namely, the potential needed to drive the reaction at a specific current density [44–46]. Due to the requirement for less energy to drive the HER process, the smaller overpotential value corresponds to better catalyst performance, and the degree of overpotential directly relates to the efficiency and cost of hydrogen production through water electrolysis. 3 MXene 3.1 Structure and performance of MXene 3.1.1 MXene structure The general formula for MXenes is M n+1X n T x (n = 1–4), which can consist of n + 1 layers of groups III-VI transition metals (M) interleaved by n layers of carbon and/or nitrogen atoms (X) and surface termination (T) on the outermost exposed M layers, such as -O, -OH, -F and -Cl [47,48]. Similar to the basal planes of MAX phases, MXenes possess a hexagonal close-packed (HCP) crystal structure with a space group symmetry of P6 3 /mmc, where X atoms occupy the octahedral interstitial sites among M atoms within the hexagonal crystal sublattice, leading to the formation of edge-sharing M6X octahedral subunits. The surface groups occupy different sites on M atoms, depending on the chemistry of T x and M [49]. Generally, MXenes are typically prepared in three steps [50]. The first step involves the synthesis of layered MXene precursors from which the crystal structure is derived; these are typically MAX (for example, M n+1AX n ) or non-MAX phase layered materials with more than one "A" atomic layer (for example, M n+1A2X n ) or with carbide layers of A elements (for example, M n A3X n+2) [51]. Second, the A atomic layers are etched away, exfoliating the precursors to produce weakly bonded MXene multilayers [52]. During the etching process of the atomic layers, the weaker M-A bonds (relative to the M-X bonds) are cleaved, resulting in the surfaces under coordinated M metallic positions rapidly becoming saturated again through reaction with T x species from the etchant. Third, the exfoliated multilayer MXene nanosheets are delaminated to yield single to few-layer MXene nanosheets [53]. The etching of Ti3AlC2 MAX phases to produce Ti3C2T x MXenes used as an example is shown in Fig. 2 a. Note that in MAX phase materials with more than one M metal element (M′ and M′′), M′ and M′′ in distinct atomic layers can be structurally ordered, while M′ and M′′ randomly distributed in the metal layers can form disordered solid solutions. The commonly investigated MXene materials are three-layer MXenes (M3X2T x ) and four-layer MXenes (M4X3T x ), such as Ti3C2T x [54] and V4C3T x [55]. Both types of structures display excellent catalytic activity in chemical reactions, driven by their unique surface functional groups and layered morphologies. Furthermore, bimetallic and high-entropy MXenes are the promising candidates for electrochemical HER applications. Yury Gogotsi et al. [58] identified Mo4VC4T x as a transitional metal MXene comprising five atomic layers, with a distinctive twinning phenomenon occurring within the M layers. In MXenes, the M sites can be populated by either a single or multiple transition metals, resulting in the formation of solid solutions or ordered structures. These ordered dual-transition metal MXenes encompass in-plane ordered configurations [i-MXenes, for instance, (Mo2/3Y1/3)2CT x ], in-plane vacancy structures (such as W2/3CT x ) and out-of-plane ordered structures (o-MXenes) [58]. These structures can feature a layer of M'' transition metal nestled between two layers of M' transition metal (like in Mo2TiC2T x ) or two layers of M'' transition metals sandwiched between two M' transition metal layers (like in Mo2Ti2C3T x ), as shown in Fig. 2 b. This architectural attribute is extraordinary in the MXene family, different from the conventional three- or four-layer structure constraint typically observed in MXenes. Cao et al. [56] found that the introduction of the secondary element with atomic dimensions comparable to the primary metal to form bimetallic MXenes. As shown in Fig. 2 c, the O-functionalized TiVC monolayer consists of a ternary atomic arrangement in the sequence Ti-C-V, with Ti and V forming the surface atomic layers and the C layer sandwiched between them [57]. Inspired by the rapid developments in high-entropy compounds and 2D MXenes, Nemani et al. [59] successfully synthesized two high-entropy MXenes with TiVNbMoC3T x and TiVCrMoC3T x . As shown in Fig. 2 d, the unit cell structures of the high-entropy MXene phase (TiM1M2M3M4T x ) show the uniform distribution of transition metals (M1, M2, M3 and M4) across the metal layers, compared with single-metal MXenes and bimetallic MXenes. 3.1.2 Stability Functional MXenes easily suffer from oxidation/degradation issues during storage and electrocatalytic applications due to their sensitivity to water and air environments [60]. This oxidation process can have a detrimental impact on the electrochemical characteristics of MXenes during the electrocatalytic HER, possibly leading to catalyst deactivation [61,62]. To address this challenge, Li et al. [63] proposed an enhanced synthesis approach that utilizes vacuum sintering to produce MXene materials ( Fig. 3 a). This method effectively minimizes the influence of atmospheric gases, resulting in a high-quality MAX phase with enhanced purity and cleanliness. Note that a disordered atomic arrangement in Ti3C2T x can result in the enhanced exposure of active titanium atoms on the surface, thereby increasing their susceptibility to oxidation and hydration processes [64]. Following this, Ti3C2T x can be treated with tetramethylammonium hydroxide (TMAOH) to remove the etching by-products and to restore oxygen-containing functional groups on the surface and edge locations, establishing a comprehensively ideal system with surface functional groups [65]. This treatment can effectively remove the fluoride residues from the surface and simultaneously enhance the adsorbing oxygen content, improving the material’s stability. The treated O-Ti3C2T x MXenes resist oxidation and degradation even after two months in a low-concentration environment (around 0.1 mg/mL), whereas conventional Ti3C2T x would fully oxidize and degrade within about 10 days under the same conditions. More interestingly, O-Ti3C2T x MXenes exhibit superior electrical conductivity, optical properties, thermal stability and biocompatibility. Yoo et al. [66] employ large-size-exfoliated MXene sheets to construct a flat and flexible substrate for anchoring Co(OH)F, CoP and Co7Se8, which significantly enhance their electrocatalytic performances owing to the optimized surface area and improved electrical conductivity. Notably, the CoP/MXene composite exhibits superior stability due to more active sites for electrocatalysis and efficient charge transfer (hierarchical structure featuring 1D porous CoP nanorods grown on 2D MXene sheets). Additionally, the formation of PO x on CoP/MXene surface during HER is favorable to improve conductivity and catalytic activity by preventing surface passivation. Zhang et al. [67] ‌demonstrated‌ that the oxidation of Ti3C2Tx ‌initiates‌ at the edges and ‌progresses‌ inward, which ‌is‌ size-dependent, with the less stability ‌observed‌ in smaller-sized lamellar structures. More interestingly, the kinetics of the oxidation of MXene flakes follow a single-exponential decay. Moreover, Huang et al. [68] highlighted that water, rather than dissolved oxygen, can serve as the dominant factor for MXene oxidation, and proposed that the actual oxidation mechanism of MXenes remains controversial and needs to further investigate the interaction of water and dissolved oxygen with MXene. 3.1.3 Electronic properties One of the most striking properties of MXene materials is the electrical conductivity, which features a fixed electron density near the Fermi level. The electronic properties of MXenes may be tuned when modified by transition metals, heterogeneous atoms or surface functional groups [69]. For example, the transition of functionalized MXenes from metals to semiconductors can be achieved by changing the type of M-group elements [70]. Meanwhile, The HER activity of MXenes can also be enhanced through modification with transition metals (TM). Gan et al. [71] investigated the stability and HER performance of TM-modified Mo2CO2 MXenes using density functional theory (DFT) calculations. The results indicated that Mo2CO2 modified with Mn and Fe at a 12.5 % monolayer (ML) coverage can exhibit ΔG H* values close to zero, suggesting promising HER applications. As shown in Fig. 3 b, the increasing electron density and weakening of the H-O bond strength induced by the more electrons from TM atoms to O atoms, lead to an increase in ΔG H*. As illustrated in Fig. 3 c, the density of states (DOS) analysis of surface-active O atoms in transition metal-doped TM-Mo2CO2 systems shows a linear correlation between the energy at the highest occupied peak (Ep) below the Fermi level and the ΔG H*. The results demonstrate that the energy level of Ep serves as a robust electronic descriptor for improving HER activity, providing a theoretical foundation for optimizing electrocatalytic performance. The electrical conductivity of MXene materials is intricately linked to their morphological characteristics [72]. Ultrathin, densely packed and well-aligned MXene nanosheets have been observed to possess exceptionally high electrical conductivity as high as 15100 S/cm [73,74]. Additionally, the highly porous structures of MXene based aerogels lead to a substantial decrease in electrical conductivity compared to their denser counterparts [75]. Experimental studies have revealed that the electrical conductivity of metallic MXenes, notably Ti3C2T x thin films, superior to that of other 2D materials including exfoliated graphene [76], metallic sulfides [77] and hydroxides [78]. Although the choice of etching method plays a pivotal role in determining the electrical conductivity of MXenes, the use of more aggressive etchants results in a higher defect density within the MXene samples [79]. Ti3C2T x powder etched only with HF can exhibit moderate electrical conductivity below 1000 S/cm [80]. Thus, altering the type and content of transition metals, the functional groups of MXenes and the etching conditions can modulate the electronic properties of MXenes to obtain the best catalytic activity. 3.2 Synthesis routes of MXene The fundamental mechanism of MXene synthesis involves selective etching to remove the "A" element layer from the MAX phases at particular environmental temperatures [50]. During the etching process, the chemical bonds between the M and A elements in the MAX phase are significantly weakened, thereby promoting the selective removal of the A element. Compared with metallic M-A bond in nature, the stronger M-X bond exhibits a combination of metallic/ionic/covalent bonding characteristics, leading to the ‘‘A” atomic layer being selectively etched from the MAX phase using HF. Under elevated temperatures, both M-A and M-X bonds undergo cleavage, resulting in the formation of a rock-like three-dimensional (3D) crystalline architecture [81]. At present, a variety of solutions are utilized as etchants, including HF [34], hydrochloric acid (HCl) and lithium fluoride (LiF) [82], potassium fluoride (KF) [83], and ammonium bifluoride (NH4HF2) [84] and so on. These precisely controlled etching processes enable atomic-scale structural customization (e.g. termination group regulation, interlayer spacing adjustment), which can synergistically enhance electrochemical performance and expand their applicability in energy storage and catalytic systems. The microstructure and surface properties of MXenes are critically influenced by a combination of factors, including the selection of etching agents, precursor composition, synthesis parameters (e.g., temperature, duration) and intercalation strategies. In addition, some of the typical MXene preparation routes and their merits and demerits are outlined in Table 1. 3.2.1 Chemical etching Direct HF etching remains‌ a fundamental and broadly employed method for preparating MXenes and derivatives. In 2011, Naguib et al. [34] successfully used this method to synthesize the accordion-like Ti3C2T x MXene ( Fig. 4 a). A ball mill was employed to blend Ti2AlC and TiC powders in a 1:1 molar ratio for a duration of 24 h. The resulting mixture was subsequently heated to 1350 ℃ under an argon atmosphere for 2 h. Next, 10 g of the powder was submerged in 100 milliliters of a 50 % concentration HF solution, which was allowed at room temperature for 2 h. This was followed by ultrasonic treatment in methanol for 300 s. Following the reaction, the suspension was thoroughly washed with deionized water on multiple occasions. The powder was then isolated via centrifugation, yielding multilayer MXene, where the layers of Ti3C2T x are bound together via hydrogen or Van der Waals bonds. The delamination of multilayered MXenes into a single layer can be achieved via ultrasonic treatment using an intercalator, such as dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) [85]. Note that MXene materials can be tailored to specific requirements by precisely controlling the reaction time, temperature, etchant concentration and the stoichiometry of HF in the solution [86]. When Ti3AlC2 is immersed in HF acid, the chemical reaction mechanism is as shown in the following Equations [34]: (7) Ti3AlC2+ 3HF=AlF3+ 3/2H2+Ti3C2 (8) Ti3C2+ 2H2O=Ti3C2(OH)2+H2 (9) Ti3C2+ 2HF=Ti3C2F2+H2 Equation (7) illustrates the first reaction between the precursor Ti3AlC2 and HF, culminating in the exfoliation of Ti3C2 layers from the pristine MAX phase as a consequence of the removal of Al atoms. Equations (8) and (9) represent the surface termination reactions, which result in the formation of multilayered MXenes with -F and -OH functional groups. It should be noted that the abovementioned equations only provide a simplified depiction of a single functional group. However, a combination of multiple terminal functional groups exists in reality, and this phenomenon is related to the employed etching methodology. Moreover, the kinetics of HF etching in MXene synthesis are influenced by HF concentration and etching time. At room temperature (25 ℃), Ti3AlC2 MAX phases are typically etched with 50 % HF for 2 h to form multilayered Ti3C2T x MXenes [34]. Notably, higher HF concentrations and elevated temperatures accelerate the etching process, leading to smaller lateral sizes and more defects in the resulting MXenes [87]. Conversely, lower HF concentrations (3 wt%) reduce toxicity and improve interlayer spacing, which is enable to prepare the ideal MXenes after longer reaction times (up to 9 h) [88]. Due to the unique crystallographic symmetry of Ti3C2, numerous dangling bonds for the exposed Ti atoms are formed on the outer surface. These bonds can easily combine with water to produce the chemically stable Ti3C2(OH)2 or with fluorine ions to form Ti3C2F2. The ending outcome of the reaction is the formation of multilayered MXene containing -OH and -F terminal functional groups, which can optimize the electrochemical properties of the MXene via the introduction of additional active sites as well as improve the overall performance of the composite-induced by enhancing interfacial adhesion between MXene and polymer matrices. The general chemical formula for MXene etched with HF is typically expressed as M n+1X n (OH) x O y F z or M n+1X n T x , where T x refers to a mixture of -OH, -O and -F surface terminations. Due to the extreme toxicity of HF, necessitating stringent safety precautions are required in the handling of HF and its waste. Consequently, a more practical approach should be explored, particularly for the large-scale production of Ti3C2T x MXene. 3.2.2 In situ HF etching HF is widely known for its severe corrosiveness and high toxicity, presenting substantial health risks, such as acute tissue necrosis, chronic pulmonary disorders and skeletal fluorosis. Furthermore, inadequate management of HF waste streams may lead to persistent environmental contamination [89]. Thus, some researchers have proposed alternative strategies that in situ etching solutions leverage the strong reactivity of fluoride (F⁻) ions toward Al atoms in MAX precursors, yielding soluble aluminum fluoride complexes, hydrogen and delaminated MXene sheets. The reaction mechanism is shown below: (10) Ti3AlC2+HCl+LiF→Ti3C2T x +AlF3+H2Ti3AlC2+HCl+LiF→Ti3C2T x +AlF3+H2 For example, Ghidiu et al. [82] demonstrated a safer alternative to HF-based etching by utilizing a mixed solution of LiF and HCl as the etchant. Through a straightforward mixing and thermal activation protocol, this method enabled the effective removal of the "A" layer in MAX phases without requiring direct HF handling. Note that the combined presence of fluoride and hydrogen ions in the mixed solution drives the form of fluorides induced by the reaction of fluoride ion and the "A" layer atoms in the MAX phase precursor, and the transformation of H+ ions into H2 gas. The spontaneous insertion of Li⁺ cations into interlayers expanded the spacing of MXene, enabling monolayer exfoliation and enhancing electrochemical performance via mild ultrasonication with manual agitation. The successfully produced MXene material exhibited clay-like properties, permitting wet-state molding into diverse geometries that could be dried into highly conductive solids or rolled into ultrathin films (Fig. 4 b). However, the ratio of LiF and HCl in the reaction medium and the presence or absence of sonication treatment critically determine the lateral dimensions and defects in the MXene flakes. It is noteworthy that the accordion-like structures of Ti3C2T x MXene etched by this method were less clear compared to those etched directly with HF [90]. Although a range of methods have been developed, the HCl/LiF etchant is still the ideal choice of in situ HF etchant. Furthermore, this method exhibits versatility, as it applies not only to Ti3AlC2 but also to various other MAX phases, such as Zr3Al3C5 [91], V2AlC [92], Mo2Ga2C [93] and Nb2GaC [94]. Moreover, the substitution of LiF with alternative fluoride salts like, KF [83], FeF3 [95], NaF [96], NH4F [97], NH4HF2 [84] and KHF2 [98] or replacement of HCl with H2SO4 has been explored for MXene etching processes. The etching outcomes vary due to the different cations introduced by the various types of fluoride salts. Ti3C2T x MXene nanosheets synthesized via fluoride-based etchants, such as KHF2 or NH4HF2, demonstrate an obvious expansion in interlayer spacing and the large 2D morphological integrity compared to those fabricated using conventional HF treatment [99]. Following the selective etching of Al atomic layers from Ti3AlC2, the resultant Ti3C2 can exhibit a negatively charged surface due to the presence of -F, -OH, and/or =O terminal groups, enabling the electrostatic adsorption of water molecules and cations from the electrolyte. This interfacial interaction can lead to an expansion in the interlayer spacing of Ti3C2. As shown in Fig. 4 c, the lattice parameter (24.8 Å) of Ti3CT x in the XRD pattern is significantly larger than that of Ti3AlC2 (18.4 Å). Liu et al. [83] successfully prepared Ti3C2 and Ti2C MXenes by selective etching of Al layers from Ti3AlC2 and Ti2AlC precursors using different fluorinated salts (LiF, KF, NaF and NH4F) combined with HCl as etchant. Various fluoride salts usually need specific reaction time and temperature for MAX phase etching [90]. For Ti3C2 MXene etching, the optimal reaction temperature and time for KF and NaF to finish the etching process were required higher temperatures (40°C) and longer durations (48 h), whereas those for NH₄F were yielded effective results at a lower temperature (30°C) in just 24 h. Further exfoliation of Ti2C MXene was achieved through the addition of urea, DMSO or NH3. Although different fluoride salts were employed during synthesis, these exfoliated MXenes can exhibit 2D accordion-like structures ( Fig. 4 d-g). Guo et al. [100] replaced HCl with H2SO4 to synthesize MXenes with enlarged interlayer spacing and ionically intercalated SO₄²⁻ groups. These groups not only facilitated expanded ionic diffusion channels but also enhanced structural stability. In comparison with MXenes etched via conventional methods (HF or LiF-HCl), the incorporation of SO₄²⁻ groups improved the specific capacitance of Ti3C2T x by approximately 66 % and 143 % (vs. HF and LiF-HCl, respectively), resulting in a significant enhancement of supercapacitor electrochemical performance. Compared with direct HF etching, the in situ HF etching method can not only optimize the structural and surface properties of MXenes but also enhance safety and environmental friendliness through milder reaction conditions. However, further refinements are required in selective layer etching, morphological uniformity control and reaction kinetics modulation to meet industrial scalability demands. 3.2.3 Molten salt etching Molten salt etching technology has emerged as an effective synthesis strategy for producing MXenes (e.g., nitride MXenes) with high formation energy. This method employs Lewis acids in molten salts (e.g., CuCl2, ZnCl2) as coordinating agents, exhibiting strong electron-accepting ligand coordination capabilities [101]. The molten salts selectively etch MAX phases by reacting with the A-layer, yielding metallic by-products while the anionic components (e.g., Cl⁻) terminate the resulting MXene surfaces. The overall etching mechanism is described by Eqs. 10 and 11: (11) Ti3AlC2 + 1.5CuCl2 = Ti3CuC2 + 0.5Cu + AlCl3 (12) Ti3CuC2 + CuCl2 = Ti3C2(Cl)2 + 2Cu This method achieves selective extraction via thermally activated ligand exchange processes, which effectively bypass the intrinsic thermodynamic barriers of traditional etching techniques [102]. The synthesis process adopted a MAX phase precursor combined with molten salts under specific temperatures and inert atmospheric conditions to initiate the reaction. During this stage, fluoride or chloride ions can selectively etch and dissolve Group A elements (e.g., Al), thereby yielding MXene layers. Li et al. [103] employed an elemental replacement method by mixing traditional MAX phase precursors (such as Ti3AlC2, Ti2AlC, Ti2AlN, and V2AlC) with molten salt ZnCl2 in a specific molar ratio, followed by a reaction under an argon atmosphere at 550°C for 5 h. Through molten salt etching method, the kinetics of the starting materials with the ratio of Ti3AlC2:ZnCl2 (1:6) heated at reaction temperature (550 ℃) is primarily governed by reaction time (0.5 h to 5 h) to investigate the phase evolution of the reaction product. Initially, Ti3AlC2 remains stable for the first 1 h, followed by the synthesis proceeded via Zn²⁺-Al replacement reactions, wherein zinc atoms occupied the A-sites within the MAX phase lattice, leading to the formation of Ti3ZnC2‌. Beyond 1.5 h, etching with excess ZnCl2 removed zinc from the A-sites in the MAX phase, enabling secondary exfoliation and simultaneous formation of MXene surfaces with Cl- functionalization. The resulting Ti3C2Cl2 can exhibit enhanced stability and electrochemical activity as promising candidates for HER and energy storage applications‌. Unlike conventional HF and in situ HF etching methods, which yield the MXene surfaces functionalized with -F leading to the reduced electrical conductivity, molten salt synthesis introduces -Cl surfaces through substitution reactions. The molten salt synthesis method of Ti3C2T x MXenes demonstrates significant advantages for electrochemical applications, particularly as high-rate anode materials in energy storage systems. This superiority stems from the enhanced oxidation stability conferred by -Cl surface terminations, which improves structural integrity during redox cycling. Compared to alternative methods, this method can show the minimal environmental impact and preserve material morphology due to the controlled reaction conditions. However, its scalability faces some challenges from elevated temperature requirements and narrow applicability to specific MAX precursors. 3.2.4 Alkali etching Li et al. [104] proposed the fabricating method of single-layered Ti3C2(OH)2 nanosheets via the etching of Ti3AlC2 precursor with KOH in DI water. The etching process removes the Al layer in Ti3AlC2 with OH groups on the surfaces. Thus, Ti3C2(OH)2 nanosheets are then obtained via simple washing. The etching mechanism is proposed as follows: (13) Ti3AlC2 + KOH + H2O → Ti3C2 + KAlO2 + 3/2H2 (14) Ti3C2 + 2H2O → Ti3C2(OH)2 + H2 These exfoliated Ti3C2(OH)2 nanosheets can restack to form a novel layered material after drying process. Through redispersing this restacked Ti3C2(OH)2 material in water, re-delamination can be achieved easily by shaking for several hours. A two-step etching process was demonstrated in 2014 for synthesizing Ti3C2T x MXenes from Ti3AlC2 MAX phase precursors [105]. This method involves sequential immersion in 1 M NaOH at 80°C (24 h) to remove interlayer Al atoms, followed by 1 M H2SO4 treatment (2 h) to eliminate surface-adsorbed Al species. This approach employs diluted alkaline solutions to minimize structural degradation. However, it suffers from suboptimal etching efficiency. Experimental evidence indicates that the removed Al reacts with OH- at lower temperatures, leading to the formation of Al(OH)3 and AlO(OH) layers on MAX-phase surfaces. These passivation layers mechanistically hinder MXene synthesis via hindering subsequent Al etching. Herein, this phenomenon termed the “jamming effect” [106,107]. Therefore, it is crucial to increase the concentration of NaOH and raise the temperature to improve the yield of MXene during the etching process. Inspired by the Bayer process employed in bauxite refinement within the aluminum industry, Li et al. [108] developed a fluoride-free MXene synthesis strategy via alkaline hydrothermal treatment‌. The successfully etching from Ti3AlC2 to produce multilayer Ti3C2T x (x = -O and/or -OH) MXene was performed in 27.5 M NaOH at 270 °C to achieve a purity of 92 wt%‌. As demonstrated in Fig. 4 h-j, the NaOH-Ti3C2T x MXene synthesized through this methodology can exhibit a more compact layered structure than that produced by direct HF etching‌. TEM and STEM analyses reveal nonuniform interlayer spacing of 1.2 nm (compared to 0.93 nm in Ti3AlC2)‌, while EIS measurements confirm that nanosheets prepared with DMSO as the intercalating agent display minimal ion transfer resistance and superior conductivity‌. This study introduced a novel alkali etching methodology utilizing elevated temperatures and high-concentration NaOH. The elevated temperature facilitates the conversion of primary products with Al(OH)3 and AlO(OH) into soluble Al(OH)4 - species, thereby enabling sustained etching progression‌. Simultaneously, the high NaOH concentration prevents the formation of non-target oxides (NTOs, e.g., Na2Ti3O7 or Na2Ti5O11), ensuring MXene purity exceeding 92 wt%‌. These advancements demonstrate significant potential for electrocatalytic HER applications‌. While concentrated alkaline etching enables the synthesis of fluorine-free MXenes with superior hydrophilicity, the inherent safety risks associated with handling strong bases under elevated temperature conditions restrict industrial scalability. The resulting accordion-like multilayered aggregates require subsequent intercalation using TMAOH or DMSO, followed by ultrasonication to isolate monolayer nanosheets. In specific chemical contexts, aluminum removal in alkaline environments necessitates elevated thermal and pressure parameters, thereby requiring integration with hydrothermal techniques to optimize efficiency [109]. Geng et al. [110] demonstrated the application of TMAOH to successfully etch Ti3AlC2. Initially, a low concentration HF solution was employed to pretreat Ti3AlC2 for a brief duration, effectively removing surface oxides. Subsequently, TMAOH was utilized as an etchant to chemically react with the material, yielding Ti3C2 terminated with Al(OH)4 -. The intercalation of tetramethylammonium cations (TMA⁺) between MXene layers facilitated interlayer expansion. More interestingly, TMAOH is predominantly applied as an intercalation agent to isolate single- or multi-layered MXenes through intercalation and ultrasonication, rather than as an etchant rarely in published studies. 3.2.5 Electrochemical etching Electrochemical etching has emerged as a promising fluoride-free strategy that enables precise control of layer spacing in MXene synthesis. The underlying mechanism involves selective removal of the “A” layer from the MAX phase through electron transfer from the “A” atoms under an applied voltage. This process induces redox reactions that facilitate the controlled etching of the “A” layer, thereby forming MXene with surface terminations such as -OH, -O, and -Cl, depending on the electrolyte composition [111]. The electrochemical system utilizes the substrate as the anode while designating the MAX phase as the cathode in an electrolyte. Layer exfoliation is induced by an applied electric potential, producing ultrathin MXene sheets with tailored physicochemical properties. Electrochemical etching provides notable advantages, such as controllable thickness with high precision and modifiable surface terminations. These characteristics are crucial for specific applications in energy storage systems and electrocatalytic processes. The selection of an optimal electrolytic system composition plays a critical role in enhancing the electrochemical etching process efficiency. For example, Yang et al. [112] reported the synthesis of single or double-layer Ti3C2T x nanosheets through a two-electrode electrochemical system employing NH4Cl and TMAOH formulated as a weakly alkaline electrolyte (pH > 9). The resulting wafers exhibited lateral dimensions of up to 18.6 μm with yields exceeding 90 %, establishing a fluorine-free electrochemical etching protocol. Pang et al. [113] proposed a thermally assisted electrochemical etching scheme of Ti2CT x , Cr2CT x and V2CT x MXenes synthesized through dilute HCl as the etchant, porous carbon fiber cloth (CFC) as the substrate and highly conductive carbon black (CB) as the conductivity-enhancing additive to construct a three-dimensional composite electrode, which establishes a novel strategy for large-scale fabrication of MXenes through a non-toxic and HF-free route. Sun et al. [114] utilized a three-electrode system with Ti2AlC as the working electrode, Ag/AgCl as the reference electrode and Pt as the counter electrode, which can selectively remove the Al layer from Ti2AlC electrodes in a HCl electrolyte under a constant applied voltage of 0.6 V. Herein, During the electrochemical etching process under conditions of 2 M HCl, Ti2AlC transforms into Ti2CT x MXene with the characteristic layered accordion-like structures for 120 h of etching and subsequently into carbide-derived carbons (CDCs) with minimal residual Ti and Al content below 1 wt% for prolonged etching with 14 days, where the presence of CDC limits further etching due to its physical barrier effect ( Fig. 5 a). This fluoride-free method demonstrates the potential for scalable MXene production, thereby facilitating industrial applications. 3.2.6 Halogen-based etching Halogen-based etching has been recognized as a novel alternative to conventional HF-based methods, offering precise control over MXene surface terminations and eliminating fluorine contamination. This process involves stirring the stoichiometric quantities of halogen-based etchants (e.g., Br2, I2, ICl, IBr) with Ti3AlC2 (MAX phase) in the presence of organic solvents, such as tetrahydrofuran (THF), acetonitrile (ACN), anhydrous cyclohexane (CH) and tetrabutylammonium halide (TBA+X-), to selectively remove the “A” element from the MAX phase [115]. Jawaid et al. [116] proposed an improved method for MXene synthesis at room temperature through halogen mediated etching of the Ti3AlC2 MAX phase using halogens (Br2, I2, ICl, IBr) under anhydrous conditions. Owing to the high reactivity of elemental halogens with Al, the principle of this process involves the introduction of Br2 to Al-containing materials, generating (AlBr3) x , where the x-mer readily dissociates into monomeric AlBr3. A radical-mediated process is critically influenced by the molar ratio of halogen to MAX phase, absolute halogen concentration, solvent type and temperature. The halogenation process schematically depicted in Fig. 5 b demonstrates that the introduction of Br2 to Ti3AlC2 in anhydrous CH induces a chromatic shift from deep red to light yellow, which is directly correlated with selective Al deintercalation through Br radical-mediated cleavage accompanied by concomitant AlBr3 formation. Shi et al. [117] utilized I2 in a halogen-based etching method for MXene synthesis, in which I2 selectively reacted with the Ti-Al bonds in Ti3AlC2, resulting in the selective removal of the Al layer and the generation of AlI3 byproducts remained embedded within the MXene interlayers. The etching byproduct AlI3 fragments were entrapped within the accordion-like multilayered structure of the synthesized MXene. Subsequent treatment with 0.1 M HCl effectively can remove the residual AlI3 and simultaneously substitute -OH/-O functionalities for -I terminal groups. The resulting MXene flakes may exhibit the enhanced electrical conductivity reported by Zhang et al. [118], which have lateral dimensions of up to 1.8 mm, exceeding those synthesized by conventional HF etching (reported values: <500 μm). Moreover, the efficiency of MXene synthesis produce can achieve 71 % under optimized conditions, with the resulting Ti3C2-I2 demonstrating a conductivity of 1250 S·cm−1, despite an extended etching duration of 4 days [117]. This method confers superior mechanical strength, flexibility and optoelectronic properties to MXene flakes relative to conventional HF-etched materials. However, the prolonged processing time and inherent toxicity of iodine-based etchants limit their practical utility in large-scale manufacturing. 3.2.7 Other novel synthesis methods The growing demand for interdisciplinary applications not only facilitates the development of novel MXene synthetic protocols but also promotes the optimization of experimental parameters. Xue et al. [119] proposed a chemical-assisted ball-milling synthesis method and synthesized fluoride-free Ti3C2 MXene with a hierarchical porous structure. As shown in Fig. 6 a, the principle of this method involves the in situ etching of Al atoms through pitting corrosion under the combined action of chemical reagents (TMAOH and LiCl) during ball milling, followed by the continuous diffusion of intermediate products such as Al(OH)4 −, TMA+, and H2, ultimately leading to the formation of the hierarchical porous structure of P-Ti3C2. The etching reaction on Ti3AlC2 proceeds as follows: (15) Ti3AlC2 + (CH3)4NOH +H2O → Ti3C2(OH) x O y + (CH3)4N[Al(OH)4] + H2 Note that ball milling disrupts the passivation layers on Ti3AlC2 surfaces, continuously exposing fresh reaction sites to sustain the etching kinetics. The resulting fluoride-free oxidized-Ti3C2 synthesized exhibits a high specific surface area (38.93 m²/g) due to its hierarchical porous structure, which is 8-fold and 234-fold higher than those of HF-etched Ti3C2 (4.87 m²/g) and pristine Ti3AlC2 (0.166 m²/g), respectively. This method is more straightforward and environmentally benign compared to alternative etching approaches. Wang et al. [120] prepared MXenes by CVD at 950°C on a Ti surface with a CH4 and TiCl4 gas mixture diluted in Ar, ‌achieving directional growth of MXenes through precise control of the composition, flow rate and temperature of the reaction gases (Fig. 6 b). The kinetics of this process involves initial uniform growth, followed by diffusion limitation, which triggers buckling and the formation of hierarchically structured MXene vesicles. This complex morphology is driven by the interplay of reaction kinetics and the elastic properties of the MXene sheets, enabling continuous growth and exposure of fresh substrate surfaces. Mei et al. [121] developed an innovative thermal reduction strategy to synthesize MXenes from sulfur-containing MAX phase precursors (Ti2SC) ( Fig. 6 c). The principle of this methodology is that sulfur atoms in the MAX phase easily react with hydrogen to form volatile gaseous byproducts (e.g., H2S), leading to MAX exfoliation into 2D Ti2C MXene nanosheets with graphene-like morphology. The reaction kinetics of this method is primarily temperature dependent. At low temperatures, slow reaction rates cause incomplete sulfur removal, resulting in a mixture of Ti2SC MAX phase and Ti2C layered structures. Increasing temperature accelerates sulfur removal, with significant elimination at 800 °C, though partial Ti2C oxidation to TiO2 occurs due to residual oxygen. Excessive temperatures (>900 °C) promote undesirable side reactions (e.g., surface etching, layer conversion to rock salt, and sulfur bonding), hindering sulfur removal. Yoon et al. [122] successfully synthesized MXene composite hybrid nanostructures incorporating various components by employing rapid Joule heating method to prevent MXene oxidation during synthesis, following the applying rapid thermal shock to the precursor-loaded MXene substrate (Fig. 6 d). The Rapid Joule heating method involves the application of a high electric current to generate rapid thermal shock, rapidly heating the MXene substrate and metal precursors to high temperatures within a short duration. This ultrafast heating process effectively "freezes" the metal nanoparticles in place on the MXene surface, preventing further coarsening or aggregation. Additionally, defect sites on the MXene surface, such as atomic vacancies and heteroatom-doped sites, facilitate the nucleation and diffusion of metal nanoparticles. The abundant surface termination groups (e.g., oxygen and hydroxyl groups) on MXene act as binding sites, enabling a dense and uniform distribution of metal nanoparticles. Importantly, the absence of aqueous processing significantly minimizes MXene oxidation, leading to the synthesis of composite hybrid nanostructures with minimal MXene damage. Despite the extensive exploration of MXene synthesis methodologies reported in the review, there are some challenges in materials manufacturing to achieve scalable commercial production that concurrently satisfies environmental sustainability, operational simplicity and economic viability. 3.3 Characterization methods X-ray diffraction (XRD) can deduce the evolution of interlayer spacing of MXene caused by different surface terminations through calculations of MXene lattice parameters, regardless of determining the elemental differences in MXene surface terminations. As shown in Fig. 7 a, with removing almost all Al elements in Ti3AlC2, the formation of Ti3C2T x MXene ‌is verified‌ by the shift of the peak from the 2θ angle of 9.20° in the MAX phase to the lower 2θ angle of 7.41° corresponding to the (002) plane, accompanied by the ‌weakening‌ of the (104) diffraction peak [123]. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) serves as a quantitative analytical technique, which not only determines the elemental composition, but also elucidates the chemical bonding configurations and oxidation states of elements present on the MXene material surface. As shown in Fig. 7 b, XPS analysis confirmed the chemical composition and functional groups of Ti3C2 MXene, revealing distinct peaks corresponding to Ti-F, Ti-C and Ti-O bonds, as well as C-C and C-O bonds, demonstrating the surface functionalization that is critical for enhancing electrocatalytic properties. As shown in Fig. 7 c, the corresponding XPS survey scan of Ti3C2T x MXene nanocomposites can confirm the predominant presence of Ti, C, O and F elements [123]. Raman spectroscopy analytical technique enables the identification of amorphous phases and the examination of transition metal oxides, and probes phonon modes (lattice vibrations). In many researches of MXene, it has been preferentially employed to provide critical insights into the bonding configurations and the water molecules intercalated between the interlayer spaces through the variation of IR spectrum. Sarycheva et al. [124] utilized Raman spectroscopy to analyze the surface chemistry, interlayer stacking, and structural quality of Ti3C2T x , revealing that the variation of Raman spectral characteristics with the synthesis method, flake dimensions and surrounding environmental conditions. As shown in Fig. 7 d, the A1g(C) peak shows the most pronounced shift among all peaks, with its lowest wavenumber (711 cm⁻¹ for HF-etched multilayer powder and 719 cm⁻¹ for HF-HCl-etched samples) corresponding to the multilayer form, where restricted vibrations result from reduced interlayer spacing and stacking. The scanning electron microscopy (SEM) technique facilitates the visualization of MXene structures. MXene synthesis can be achieved through immersion in concentrated HF, with the characteristic "accordion-like" morphology serving as a sign of successful preparation [34]. Through SEM analysis shown in Fig. 7 e and Fig. 7 f, Ti2AlC MAX phases possess a layered structure with well-defined stacking morphology, while Ti3C2T x MXene displays characteristic accordion-like multilayers, confirming successful Al layer removal via HF etching [125]. High-Resolution Transmission Electron Microscopy (HRTEM) presents the characterization of MXenes by resolving atomic-level structures, such as interlayer spacing, surface termination groups, and crystallographic details. For instance, through the HRTEM analysis shown in Fig. 7 g, the crystal structure of Ti3C2 MXene corresponds to the (002) plane, and the plane spacing of is 1.35 nm [126]. In addition to single-metal MXenes, the morphological characteristics of bimetallic and high-entropy MXenes were also given, which were applied to investigate the great potential in electrochemical applications. As shown in Fig. 8 a and Fig. 8 b, ultrasonication of multilayered TiVC MXene expand the interlayer spacing with a transition from the accordion-like morphology into a 2D monolayer structure (a-TiVC) [56]. Due to ion exchange and directional crystal cleavage induced by subsequent alkalization with KOH, TiVC nanosheets transform into nanoribbons which shows a 3D interwoven nanoribbon-nanosheet structure, as shown in Fig. 8 c. Using HRTEM images shown in Fig. 8 d, the crystal structure and plane spacing of 0.23 nm confirms the a-TiVC nanosheets have high crystallinity with the HCP structure. Through the analysis of SEM images shown in Fig. 8 e and Fig. 8 f, high-entropy TiVNbMoC3T x and TiVCrMoC3T x reveal accordion-like multilayer morphologies, consistent with single-metal and bimetallic MXenes [59]. Furthermore, STEM and energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) analyses further confirm uniformly distributed Ti, V, Nb/Cr, Mo, and C atoms in the layered morphologies of TiVNbMoC3T x and TiVCrMoC3T x ( Fig. 8 g). The synthesis of high-entropy MXenes greatly broadens the compositional diversity of the MXene family, enabling further tuning their properties, such as electronic, magnetic, electrochemical, catalytic, high-temperature stability and mechanical behaviors. 4 MXene electrocatalysts in HER The electrocatalytic mechanism of MXenes for HER includes multiple steps, which can be described as adsorption of hydrogen ions (protons) at the MXene catalyst՛s interface, proton reduction to form hydrogen gas molecules and subsequent desorption of these molecules from the catalyst՛s surface [127]. Table 2 summarizes the catalytic performance of various MXene electrocatalysts for HER. Note that the large surface area, high electrical conductivity and favorable electrochemical properties of multilayered accordion-like morphology MXenes efficiently promote the adsorption, electrochemical reduction, and subsequent desorption of hydrogen ions and molecules. Furthermore, the intercalation of agents (such as DMSO and TMAOH) enables the exfoliation of accordion-like multilayered MXene into few-layer or monolayer structures. This significantly grows the electrochemically surface area (ECSA), which is essential for improving electrocatalytic performance in the HER. The microstructure and surface properties of MXenes can be precisely regulated by adjusting precursor selection, the choice of etchants and synthesis conditions (temperature and time). The rational design of MXene composites through doping, surface functionalization and heterostructuring can not only improve electrocatalytic efficiency, facilitating the development of scalable and cost-effective catalysts, but also exhibit transformative potential in mitigating global energy crises and environmental pollution. The catalytic performance of different MXene based nanocomposites for hydrogen production are summarized in Table 3. 4.1 Pristine MXenes for HER Kumar et al. [138] conducted a systematic evaluation of seven MAX phases (Ti2AlC, Ta2AlC, Ti2SnC, Ti3SiC2, V2AlC, Mo2TiAlC2 and Cr2AlC) through electrochemical analysis using a glassy carbon (GC) working electrode in 0.5 M H2SO4 electrolyte. SEM images revealed that the Ti2AlC, V2AlC, Ta2AlC and Cr2AlC MAX phases can exhibit stacked sheet-like layered structures, while Ti2SnC, Ti3SiC2 and Mo2TiAlC2 can display round and clumpy morphologies. Moreover, EDS analysis further confirmed the elemental composition ( Fig. 9 a). As demonstrated by the linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) and Tafel slope comparisons of the seven materials in Fig. 9 b, Ti2SnC exhibits the lowest Tafel slope to improve electrocatalytic reaction kinetics. Note that surface metal engineering plays the pivotal role in the electrochemical performance hierarchy of MXenes (Mo2TiAlC2 > V2AlC > Cr2AlC > Ti2SnC > Ti2AlC > Ta2AlC > Ti3SiC2). Dual-metal layered MXenes (e.g., Mo2TiAlC2) exhibit excellent performance superior to the single-metal counterparts owing to the harnessing of intermetallic electronic interactions, which accelerate reaction kinetics as demonstrated by the reduced Tafel slopes and overpotentials. In the case of Mo2TiAlC2, Ti atoms positioned between adjacent Mo layers and structurally bonded to removable Al form a stacking arrangement denoted as Mo-Ti-Mo-Al-Mo-Ti-Mo. This unique configuration, where the exposed Mo atoms reside within Ti layers, introduces distinct surface and electrical characteristics absent in standard Ti2AlC. Consequently, Mo2TiAlC2 possesses a lower overpotential (-0.57 V vs. RHE) compared to Ti2AlC (-0.76 V vs. RHE). The complex atomic architecture of Mo2TiAlC2 dictates its superior HER performance, thereby establishing Mo, Ti and V as the primary metallic constituents that produce the most efficient MXene catalysts for HER activity. 4.2 Surface functionalized MXenes for HER During the etching process of MXenes (M n+1X n T x ), the removal of the "A" layer leads to the introduction of surface termination groups (-O, -OH, -F and -Cl) onto the MXene surface. Surface functionalization of MXene significantly enhances its HER performance by modulating its electronic structure, increasing active sites and optimizing surface chemistry [153]. The types of MXene surface terminations are potentially dependent on the selection of etching agent, washing and delamination method during the synthesis process of MXene. For example, in situ HF etching preferentially forms -O terminal groups, while direct HF etching primarily generates -F groups on MXene surfaces. Moreover, surface functional groups critically adjust the structural stability of MXenes [154]. For instance, -OH groups readily undergo decomposition, -F groups are susceptible to desorption or replacement by heteroatoms owing to weak ionic M-F bonding, while -O groups exhibit superior stability by passivating inner transition metal atoms against environmental exposure, thereby enhancing oxidation resistance and demonstrating exceptional durability in acidic electrolytic environments [155]. The heterostructure catalysts of O-terminated R-CoC2O4@MXene can keep stable after 100 h at the current densities of 10, 500 and 1000 mA/m2 in acidic electrolytes, demonstrating long-term stability [156]. Moreover, MXene might exploit its surface to interact with the hydroxide ions in alkaline media, hindering the kinetic reaction. Although some MXene-based composites (e.g., ZIF-8/MXene) exhibit 20 h stability in alkaline media, long-term durability remains a concern due to susceptibility to deterioration [157]. For neutral environments, the stability of O-functionalized MXenes is influenced by the local pH, which affects the protonation/deprotonation equilibrium of surface groups. For instance, in 1.0 M PBS electrolyte (neutral pH), CoP@MXene showed a short-term stability for 20 h [158]. Handoko et al. [139] conducted the combined theoretical and experimental investigations to examine the role of fluorine termination in Ti- and Mo-based MXenes on HER performance. These results show that an elevated density of surface -F groups suppresses HER activity. Although the -F terminations exhibit negligible hydrogen adsorption capacity, they facilitate hydrogen release by abstracting protons from neighboring -OH groups, thereby generating H2 molecules. DFT calculations revealed that -F terminations exhibit negligible hydrogen adsorption free energy (ΔG H* ≈ 1.2 eV), whereas -OH or -O groups (ΔG H* ≈ 0.1–0.3 eV). Experimentally, fluorinated MXenes under acidic HER conditions showed significantly reduced current densities and increased overpotentials, which are attributed to the disruption of Volmer step kinetics, ultimately leading to diminishing the HER activity. The exfoliation of multilayered MXene into few- or monolayer structures via intercalation agents substantially can enhance the ECSA of the catalyst. Jiang et al. [128] subjected Ti3AlC2 powder to chemical etching in a 50 wt% HF aqueous solution at 60°C for 24 h, selectively removing the Al layer to obtain multilayered Ti3C2T x MXene (where Tₓ represents surface terminations such as -F and -OH). Following intercalation with DMSO, the mixture was subjected to ultrasonication in an aqueous medium, yielding exfoliated Ti3C2Tₓ (E-Ti3C2T x ) nanosheets ( Fig. 9 c). Surface terminal -F groups on E-Ti3C2T x were replaced with -OH groups through dispersion in a KOH aqueous solution, yielding E-Ti3C2(OH) x . Subsequent calcination at 450°C for 3 h under an Ar atmosphere converted the -OH groups into O-functionalized Ti3C2 MXene, resulting in E-Ti3C2O x . Electrochemical analyses confirmed that O-terminated MXenes exhibit enhanced performance compared to the -OH or -F terminated counterparts. Beyond surface functionalization of Ti3C2T x MXene, analogous chemical modification strategies have been effectively extended to other MXenes (e.g., Ti2N, Ti4N3, Nb2C and Nb4C3), achieving enhanced HER catalytic efficiency through targeted terminal group engineering. Zhang et al. [140] prepared Pd nanocatalysts supported on Nb2CT x with different surface functional groups. Etching Nb2CT x in a 50 % HF solution to yield fluorine-terminated Nb2C-HF resulted in a Pd/Nb2C-HF composite with substantial retention of surface-bound -F groups. Subsequent immersion of Nb2C-HF in H2SO4 and HNO3 aqueous solutions introduced -SO4 2- and nitrate -NO3 - terminations, respectively. DFT calculations of the optimized structures and adsorption energies of hydrogen atoms on different functionalized Nb2C surfaces were as shown in Fig. 9 d. The results indicated that the presence of -F groups significantly weakens the hydrogen adsorption ability, which is beneficial for enhancing the HER performance of the catalyst. Modification of the etching protocol enables the fabrication of 3D porous MXene electrocatalysts, which exhibit enhanced specific surface area, increased active site density and reduced ion transport distances to optimize electrocatalytic reaction kinetics. Hong et al. [141] synthesized 3D Ti3C2T x MXene with enhanced specific surface area by modulating the solution PH. Subsequent treatment with NaOH and HF yielded MXene materials functionalized with distinct groups (-O, -OH and -F). With precise modulation of the Pt loading level, Pt nanoparticles were then deposited onto the 3D MXene carrier via the polyol method. Through DFT calculations, the formation energies of −0.26 eV, −3.19 eV and −3.65 eV for Pt/Ti3C2F2, Pt/Ti3C2O2 and Pt/Ti3C2(OH)2 model structures confirmed the thermodynamic stability of all MXene catalysts. However, the formation energies of Pt/Ti3C2F2 indicated the less favorable Pt integration on -F-terminated surfaces. Furthermore, the calculated onset potentials (η = 12 mV) and hydrogen adsorption energies (ΔG H* = −0.08 eV) demonstrated that -OH terminations optimize the HER activity of Pt-based catalysts. Although the direct modification of functional group configurations constitutes some potential strategy for enhancing electrocatalytic activity in the HER, this approach proves insufficient for developing the promising catalysts with both superior catalytic performance and expanded applicability across diverse operational contexts. Therefore, beyond modulating MXene's intrinsic functional groups, an alternative methodology involves synthesizing single-atom catalysts through metal atom introduction via functional group displacement or surface doping. This atomic engineering strategy enables the precise optimization of MXene's electronic structure while generating abundant active sites, thereby regulating hydrogen adsorption/desorption dynamics and substantially enhancing HER catalytic efficiency. Gong et al. [142] synthesized Pt single atoms (SAs) anchored at oxygen vacancies (OV) within a monolayer Ti3C2T x matrix (Ti3C2T x -PtSA) via an ultrafast thermal annealing protocol in a hydrogen atmosphere. The synthesized single-atom catalyst can have the exceptional HER performance with robust stability, high intrinsic activity and a large turnover frequency. Compared to monoatomic catalysts, diatomic catalysts exhibit enhanced metal loading capacity and structurally versatile active sites. This diatomic configuration facilitates optimized adsorption energetics for multiple intermediates via synergistic d-band center modulation, consequently enhancing HER kinetics [159]. Zhao et al. [160] developed a surface-modification strategy for MXene substrates through L-tryptophan pre-adsorption, enabling the attachment of dual-atom Co/Ni electrocatalysts onto Ti3C2T x surfaces via N-Co/Ni-O bonding. This approach can achieve a high metal loading of 5.6 wt%, thereby increasing active site density and enhancing electrocatalytic performance. During the experiment, Ti3C2T x MXene was synthesized by etching with LiF/HCl (35℃, 24 h), followed by centrifugal washing with deionized water until pH 4. The MXene was subsequently functionalized with L-tryptophan in ethanol under N2 atmosphere (50°C, 6 h), yielding Try-Ti3C2T x . Cryogenically solidified CoCl2/NiCl2 precursors were then reacted with Try-Ti3C2T x in ethanol to fabricate the CoNi-Ti3C2T x composite, as illustrated in Fig. 9 e. The CoNi-Ti3C2T x electrocatalyst can demonstrate the exceptional HER performance, requiring a minimal overpotential of 31 mV@10 mA cm−2 and exhibiting a Tafel slope of 33 mV dec⁻¹ . Notably, the composite material displayed sustained operational stability for HER over 100 h at an industrially relevant current density of 500 mA cm⁻². 4.3 Doped atoms MXene for HER Metal atom doping enhances the HER performance of MXenes primarily by modulating their electronic structure and introducing active sites. Doping transition metals (e.g., Pt, Co, Ni) into MXene lattices alters the electron distribution, optimizes the adsorption/desorption kinetics of hydrogen intermediates, and creates localized electronic states that facilitate charge transfer [161]. For instance, single-atom doping of Pt or Co into MXenes stabilizes metal atoms via strong covalent bonds, reducing the overpotential for HER. Additionally, heteroatom incorporation (e.g., N, S) further tunes the surface chemistry by forming polar bonds or defects, which enhance proton diffusion and electron conductivity. 4.3.1 Metal-doped MXene for HER Among all noble-metal catalysts, Pt and its alloys have been extensively investigated owing to their superior electrocatalytic activity and corrosion resistance in both alkaline and acidic media. Yuan et al. [143] reported a new composite catalyst based on Pt-infused MXene to optimize electrocatalytic HER efficiency, where Ti3C2T x (T = -O, -OH, -F) substrates were synthesized through surface termination engineering and followed by Pt deposition via wet-impregnation and photo-induced reduction method. Alkaline treatment of Ti3C2T x using KOH (1.8 M) and tetrabutylammonium hydroxide (TBAOH, 0.04 M) facilitates cation intercalation, where K⁺ and TBA⁺ ions replace interlayer H⁺ protons, yielding modified derivatives designated as K-Ti3C2T x and TBA-Ti3C2T x . Among the wet immersion catalysts, TBA-Ti3C2T x -Pt-20 (“20”‌ typically denotes the ‌nominal weight percentage of Pt added during synthesis) demonstrated notable catalytic performance, exhibiting the overpotentials of 55 mV at a current density of 10 mA cm−2. Pt nanoparticles were deposited on the conductive Ti3C2T x support, where the electronic state of Pt was modulated by O-terminated or OH-terminated Ti3C2, enabling rapid interfacial charge transfer. This optimized charge transfer between the O-terminated surface and Pt nanoparticles significantly enhanced the HER kinetics. Although Pt catalysts as precious metals have the exceptional HER activity, their inherent scarcity including prohibitive cost and restricted availability poses substantial barriers to industrial implementation. Consequently, it is necessary to develop low-Pt-loading or non-precious-metal catalysts via atomic-scale engineering of high-surface-area porous nanostructures to improve Pt utilization efficiency and optimize catalytic performance, such as single-atom catalysts, nanoclusters and heterostructures. Following this strategic approach, Cui et al. [144] developed a stratified Pt-Ti3C2T x -single-walled carbon nanotube (SWCNT) heterostructures by anchoring Pt nanoparticles or atomic-level Pt species onto Ti3C2T x MXene flakes. Leveraging the intrinsic hydrophilicity and reducibility of MXene, Pt cations undergo spontaneous reduction to metallic Pt without requiring external reducing agents or post-treatment. The observed positive charge on Pt atoms indicates heterojunction-like Pt/Ti3C2T x interfacial interactions, which enhance HER catalyst stability under operational conditions. Jian et al. [145] proposed a strategy for the rapid synthesis of ultra-low platinum nanoclusters (NCs) on 2D Ti3C2T x MXene substrates to create an efficient catalyst. The MXene substrates offer abundant catalytic active sites for NCs anchoring while enhancing ECSA through optimized charge redistribution. Modulating electrochemical deposition parameters enabled the fabrication of Ti3C2T x substrates with ultralow loading yet uniformly dispersed Pt nanoclusters. Electrochemical testing of the resulting Pt NCs-MXene materials demonstrated a significant enhancement in HER activity in acidic environments compared to unmodified MXene. Beyond Pt-based systems, noble metal-doped MXene composites have attracted significant attention for HER applications. A one-step in situ reduction approach was developed by etching Mo2Ga2C precursors in HCl-LiF-RuCl3 solution, where Ru3+ ions were simultaneously reduced to metallic Ru clusters (≈50 nm aggregates composed of 5 nm grains) anchored on Mo2CT x nanosheets [162]. This in situ doping strategy achieves direct noble metal (e.g., Ru, Pt) anchoring on MXene substrates during etching, eliminating post-synthetic acid washing or thermal treatments mandated in conventional surface doping approaches. Uniformly distributed Ru clusters (∼50 nm diameter) on Mo2CT x flakes ( Fig. 10 a) exhibit nanoscale Ru grains (∼5 nm) in their morphology (Fig. 10 f, g), suggesting abundant catalytic active sites. The MXene substrates effectively stabilize Ru dispersion (Fig. 10 b-e), suppressing particle aggregation to enhance catalytic activity and stability. Ru/Mo2CT x can exhibit exceptional HER performance in phosphate buffer (ƞ 10 =73 mV, Tafel slope =57 mV dec−1), originating from synergistic interactions between Ru nanoclusters and the hydrophilic MXene surfaces. DFT calculations demonstrate the lower energy barrier for H2O dissociation barrier (0.5 eV) and optimize ΔG H* (≈0.1 eV) for Ru clusters on Mo2CT x substrates, indicating the enhancing HER performance. Transition metal/metalloid-doped MXenes have garnered considerable research interest as promising electrocatalysts for HER. Wu et al. [148] constructed tellurium (Te)-doped V2C/V2O3 electrocatalyst through mild H2O2 oxidation and calcination treatments ( Fig. 11 a). This work rationally exploits the inherent susceptibility to oxidation of MXene to modify the interfacial structures, thereby obtaining a stable self-generated vanadium-based heterointerfaces. More interestingly, the microteaching effect of H2O2 creates a multitude of pores, addressing the restacking issue, while the doping of Te elements resolved the dilemma of intermediate absorption/desorption capacity. Zhang et al. [147] have successfully fabricated a Vp-Co-MoP@MXene heterostructures with a nanorod-like structures through a simple hydrothermal method, followed by high-temperature phosphorization and reduction processes. This heterostructures due to Co doping modulate the surface electronic structures and charge redistribution of MoP, while the phosphorous vacancy Vp induces more defects and active sites. Simultaneously, the spontaneous interfacial built-in electric field (BIEF) accelerates the interfacial charge transfer rate between Vp-Co-MoP and MXene. Consequently, the synergistic integration of Vp-Co-MoP/MXene heterostructures effectively reduces the activation energies and kinetic barriers, thereby enhancing its intrinsic catalytic activity and structural stability. Sajjad Hussain et al. [163] systematically investigated the HER performance of 24 transition metal single-atom catalysts anchored on MXene surfaces (Mo2CT2, T = O or S) via first-principles calculations, analyzing the binding sites on Mo2CO2 and Mo2CS2 substrates (Fig. 11 b). Adsorption energy calculations revealed negative values for all transition metal atoms anchored to these MXene surfaces ( Fig. 11 c), demonstrating spontaneous stabilization through surface-substrate interactions. For Mo2CO2 surfaces, Zr exhibits the maximum binding energy (-7.81 eV), while Au shows the minimum value (-1.08 eV). However, for Mo2CS2 surfaces, Zr similarly displays the highest binding energy (-3.84 eV), while Cr has the lowest value (-0.27 eV). The interfacial electronic coupling between transition metal atoms and MXene supports with functional groups (e.g. -O and -S) modulates the catalyst's electronic configuration, which simultaneously enhances hydrogen adsorption capacity and stabilizes single-atom dispersion by preventing aggregation, thereby preserving high-density active sites to improve both HER catalytic activity and operational stability. Hu et al. [164] conducted high-throughput calculations of local structural and corresponding electronic structural changes for Ti2CO2 and Zr2CO2 doped with a plethora of transition metal single atoms to analyze to investigate HER performance. They also developed universal electronic descriptors using the Sure Independence Screening and Sparsity Optimization (SISSO) method, which coordinated the trends of ΔG H* for various MXenes substrates doped with transition metal atoms. These descriptors enabled the prediction that doping with Cr, Fe, Ru, Pd, Os, and Ir atoms would be favorable for optimizing the ΔG H* of HF2CO2, thereby reducing ΔG H* from 1.082 eV to within ±0.2 eV. This study not only demonstrates transition metal dopants markedly improving the catalytic activity of MXenes through electronic structure modulation, but establishes generalizable electronic descriptors as a robust framework for accelerating the discovery of high efficiency HER catalysts. 4.3.2 Non-metal doped MXene for HER Metal-doped MXene catalysts constitute a shifting development in electrocatalysis, specifically for HER performance. Note that the prohibitive costs of noble metals (including Pt, Pd and Ru) with superior intrinsic activity and the catalytic efficiency and durability of transition metals (including Ti, Mo, V, and Nb) with economic viability limit scalable applications in industry. Strategic surface doping of these non-metals onto MXene substrates generates hierarchical nanostructures with expanded electroactive surface areas, directly correlating with increased density of catalytic sites and enhanced charge transfer kinetics. Recent investigations revealed that N, B, P, and S-doped MXene catalysts attain HER performance comparable to noble metals through optimized synthesis protocols and interfacial engineering. These heteroatom-modified architectures demonstrate considerable potential as sustainable alternatives to metal-based systems, with their earth-abundance and low synthesis costs ensuring scalable production while maintaining electrochemical stability. Ding et al. [165] conducted DFT calculations to investigate the impact of heteroatom X (X = N, B, P and S) doping on the HER catalytic activity of M2C MXene (M = Ti, Mo). The basic structures including the adsorption sites of MXene materials doped oxygen atoms ( Fig. 12 a). N-doping in Ti2C/Mo2C (N-M2C) was computationally modeled through C-to-N atomic substitution, where ehe doping sites and corresponding hydrogen adsorption configurations (top, bridge, hollow) were comprehensively analyzed to elucidate their structural and energetic properties in Fig. 12 b. N-Ti2CO2 exhibits a near-zero ΔG H* value (0.087 eV), indicating that the HER catalytic activity can be comparable to the Pt reference catalyst (ΔG H*≈0.09 eV; Fig. 12 c). Furthermore, electronic structure analysis of X-doped Ti2CO2 systems demonstrates that N doping can significantly enhance the electrical conductivity relative to pristine Ti2CO2. In previous studies, Han et al. [149] developed an innovative ultrasonic treatment strategy to synthesize Ti3C2T x MXene with precise regulation of N doping content through modulation of the ultrasonic treatment temperature (Fig. 12 d). The N doping process involves subjecting Ti3C2T x to 30-minute ultrasonication in an aqueous solution containing NH3 and sodium borohydride (NaBH4). Ultrasonication-induced mechanical vibrations and cavitation effects facilitate homogenization of the reaction system and activation of the NH3-MXene interfacial reactions, thereby enabling Ti-N bond formation. Remarkably, this protocol enables the synthesis of N-doped Ti3C2T x without post-synthetic thermal treatment. Concomitant with ultrasonication, selective elimination of O-containing functional groups generates vacancy defects, which are subsequently occupied by nitrogen species. This defect engineering strategy yields multiple nitrogen configurations, namely C-NH2, C-NH, Ti-N, and Ti-NH2 moieties. The methodology specifically targets the removal of kinetically labile -O functionalities via prolonged ultrasonication at a controlled temperature of 35°C. Subsequently, Le et al. [150] proposed a simple and universal strategy to enhance the hydrogen evolution catalytic performance of Ti3C2T x MXenes by employing NH3 gas thermal treatment, achieved through the modification of N-doped atoms. The Ti3C2T x MXene was subjected to thermal treatment in an NH3 atmosphere for 3 h at different temperatures (200, 400, 600 and 800 °C) using a quartz tube furnace, with an NH3 flow rate maintained at 200 mL/min. Experimental results demonstrated that N-doped Ti3C2T x annealed at 600 °C can exhibit superior HER electrocatalytic activity compared to pristine Ti3C2T x .
