Conventional N doping processes require post-synthetic annealing steps, inducing oxidative degradation of the material through prolonged exposure to elevated temperatures. As shown in Fig. 12 e, experimental results revealed that N-doped Ti3C2T x annealed at 600 °C (N-Ti3C2T x @600) exhibited superior HER performance with an overpotential of 198 mV at 10 mA cm−2, compared to 560, 410, and 390 mV for N- Ti3C2T x annealed at 200 °C (N-Ti3C2T x @200), 400 °C (N-Ti3C2T x @400) and 800 °C (N-Ti3C2T x @800), respectively. As shown in Fig. 12 f, the corresponding Tafel slopes were measured to be 268, 107, 101, 99, 92 and 35 mV dec−1 for pristine Ti3C2T x , N-Ti3C2T x @200, N-Ti3C2T x @400, N-Ti3C2T x @600, N-Ti3C2T x @800, and Pt/C, respectively. The results confirmed the superior HER kinetics of N-doped Ti₃C₂Tₓ annealed at 600 °C. Although previous studies have demonstrated the potential of N-doped 2D MXenes for electrocatalytic HER performance, the low catalytic intrinsic activity and propensity for restacking result is still unsatisfactory in electrocatalytic performance in practical applications. To address this issue, Nguyen et al. modified the electronic structures and increased the interlayer spacing of Ti3C2T x MXenes by NH3-assisted hydrothermal method, systematically exploring the impact of different synthesis temperatures on the nitrogen doping mechanism to optimize the HER performance of N-doped Ti3C2T x MXenes [151]. The study found that N-doped Ti3C2T x MXenes prepared at 160°C can exhibit the highest HER activity with overpotential/Tafel slope values of 186.91 mVRHE/115.94 mVRHE dec−1 in an acidic solution, superior to that of the pristine Ti3C2T x MXene. Specifically, phosphorus (P) with lone-pair electrons in the 3p orbitals and unoccupied 3d orbitals enables surface charge redistribution through local electron density modulation, thereby rendering P-doped MXenes promising candidates for HER performance enhancement. Tekalgne et al. [152] synthesized Ti3C2T x MXenes through selective etching of Ti3AlC2 precursors, followed by P doping via hydrothermal treatment using NH4H2PO4. Subsequent heterostructure fabrication employed CoCl2∙6 H2O and thiourea as Co and S sources, yielding CoS2-P-Ti3C2T x nanocomposites ( Fig. 13 a). The hierarchical architectures provide additional active sites and improve charge transfer kinetics. The uniform dispersion of CoS2 nanoparticles can significantly improve electrode-electrolyte interfacial contact, thereby enhancing hydrogen adsorption energetics and proton reduction efficiency. MXene can be integrated with other 2D materials (e.g. graphene) to engineer heterostructures incorporating dopant atoms. Through concurrent construction of heterostructures and interface engineering alongside atomic doping, these synergistic strategies effectively optimize the catalytic charge transfer kinetics and enhance active sites. Qin et al. [166] performed DFT calculations to investigate the electronic properties and HER catalytic behavior of MXene/N-doped graphene (NDG) heterostructures. The analysis revealed electron density depletion in NDG layers and concomitant electron accumulation in MXene layers, demonstrating interfacial electron transfer upon heterostructure formation. The computed free energy diagrams under mono hydrogen coverage show that MXene/NDG heterostructures exhibit significantly lower ΔG H* compared to pristine NDG, confirming the enhanced hydrogen adsorption capacity and consequently improved HER activity. Xu et al. [131] synthesized a robust trifunctional electrocatalyst by synergistically coupling N-doped delaminated niobium carbide (N-Nb4C3T x ) nanosheets and N-doped graphitic carbon (NGC) (referred to as N-Nb4C3T x /NGC). The structural properties and nitrogen content of the MXene were regulated by adjusting the mass ratio of Nb4C3T x to hexamethylenetetramine (HMTA), and the preparation was carried out through polymerization and thermal annealing, as depicted in Fig. 13 b. SEM analysis reveals the hierarchical porous nanoflower architectures of N-Nb4C3T x /NGC-6, including interconnected MXene nanosheets bridged by HMTA-derived polymeric networks that collectively form the 3D wrinkled microstructures (Fig. 13 c). An interlayer spacing of 1.09 nm indicates the few-layer Nb4C3T x stacking configuration within this nanoflower assembly (Fig. 13 d, e). The engineered architectures designed by the synergistic coupling strategy between N-Nb4C3T x and NGC not only facilitate efficient proton transport pathways to improve electrocatalytic performance for HER, OER, and overall water splitting, but also establishe a novel paradigm for developing cost-effective MXene based electrocatalytic systems. 4.4 MXene heterostructures for HER In the field of electrocatalytic HER, MXene can be integrated with other materials to construct heterostructures [159]. These heterostructures expand the effective catalytic area with more active sites and facilitate spontaneous interfacial electron transfer driven by work function differences, simultaneously modulating the electronic structures of the composite materials. This synergistic approach optimally combines the structural merits of heterojunction components, thereby significantly enhancing the overall electrocatalytic performance [101]. Notably, MXenes still have some inherent limitations in electrocatalytic applications. For example, during hydrothermal etching of Ti3C2, dissolved oxygen in an aqueous solution combines with the most active edges of MXene to generate TiO2, leading to structural changes and degradation of electrochemical properties [67]. Therefore, engineering MXene based heterostructures with enhanced activity and operational stability has emerged as a vital strategy for developing high efficiency electrocatalysts. The integration of MXene with graphene, nickel foam (NF), LDHs, MOFs, TMCs, TMSs，nitrogen-doped carbon (NC), transition metal phosphides (TMPs), metal oxides/ sulfides/ phosphides et al. enables the construction of heterostructures that effectively suppress MXene nanosheets restacking and establish efficient ion transport pathways. Recently, the reported MXene based heterostructured electrocatalyst were listed in Table 4 for HER performance. Graphene has emerged as a foremost energy material owing to its exceptional electrical conductivity, superior thermal properties, chemical stability, remarkable mechanical strength and high surface area. The abundant oxygen-functional groups on graphene surfaces provide the structural basis which is favorable to construct effective integration with other materials [187]. Consequently, integrating MXene with graphene represents a promising strategy for synergistically enhancing electrocatalytic performance. Yu et al. [167] synthesized Ru nanoclusters integrated with hierarchical exfoliated-MXene/reduced graphene oxide architectures (Ru-E-MXene/rGA) through a one-step solvothermal approach utilizing the reductive ability of ethylene glycol. The self-assembled graphene oxide hierarchical Ru-E-MXene/rGA structures effectively resist the restacking of MXene nanosheets and strongly trap Ru³ ⁺ ions at the interfaces, facilitating uniform dispersion of Ru nanoclusters within the composite. Owing to controlled morphology and optimized surface chemistry, the Ru-E-MXene/rGA shows exceptional HER performance over a broad pH range. Zhu et al. [168] successfully synthesized a 3D nanoflower-like NiFe-LDH/MOF heterostructured electrocatalyst based on MXene through an in situ semi-transformation (ISST) strategy. MXene was first attached to NF as a substrate via electrostatic self-assembly, followed by the preparation of NiFe-MOF through a static self-loading method. Considering the instability of oxalate MOF under alkaline conditions, NiFe-MOF/LDH composite was further generated via ISST-assisted hydrothermal treatment in alkaline environments, followed by the introduction of metal cationic defects through a secondary hydrothermal process. This method facilitates the formation of a heterogeneous electrocatalyst, which not only have abundant phase interfaces and optimized electronic structures via the composite of MOFs and LDHs, but also pose rich exposed active sites provided by the lamellar nanoflower morphology of LDHs. The electrocatalysts show exceptional electrochemical performance with a HER overpotential of 143 mV, and maintain excellent stability even at high current densities, highlighting its potential as a bifunctional catalyst for industrial-scale applications. Feng et al. [172] successfully synthesized an efficient bifunctional electrocatalyst by constructing CoSe-Ni0.95Se heterostructure coupled with Ti3C2T x MXene to improve HER and hydrazine oxidation reaction (HzOR) performance in hydrazine-assisted water splitting. The synergistic coupling of MXene heterostructures modulates the coordination structure of Ni and Co species, leading to the redistribution of interfacial electronic field and the facilitation of directional electron transfer from Ni0.95Se to CoSe. The existence of MXene can anchor more active sites, which consequently results in the formation of abundant nucleophilic CoSe and electrophilic Ni0.95Se that can modulate the d-band center, adjust the ΔG H* and promote the adsorption/desorption of hydrazine intermediates, thereby contributing to effective HER and HzOR performance. These findings establish a novel framework for designing high-performance non-precious metal catalysts with balanced activity and stability. Ma et al. [188] developed a composite material with atomically dispersed Ru single atoms (RuSAs) anchored on the MoSe2/MXene heterointerface (denoted as RuSAs@MoSe2-MXene) via heterointerface engineering. The heterostructure with fully exposed and catalytically active Mo edge sites was constructed by hydrothermally depositing ultrathin curved 2H-MoSe2 nanosheets onto Ti3C2T x MXene. Furthermore, the atomic dispersion of RuSAs across both MoSe2 and MXene substrates maximizes metal utilization efficiency, thereby improving the catalytic activity. Electrochemical evaluation in 0.5 M H2SO4 via a three-electrode system revealed that RuSAs@MoSe2-MXene achieves an ultralow overpotential of 49 mV at 10 mA cm−2, outperforming MoSe2-MXene (96 mV) and pristine MXene (212 mV), with a Tafel slope of 52 mV dec−1 ( Fig. 14 a, b). Zhou et al. [125] prepared a bifunctional electrocatalyst by interfacing Ce-doped CoSe2 nanoneedle arrays with MXene through a simple hydrothermal and selenization process, resulting in the formation of Ce-CoSe2/MXene. The nanoneedle array morphology of Ce-CoSe2/MXene (Fig. 14 d-f) enhances the specific surface area, thereby increasing active site density for electrocatalytic processes. DFT calculations reveal a near-optimal ΔG H* (0.44 eV) for Ce-CoSe2/MXene, indicating a minimal energy barrier for H* adsorption, thereby enhancing HER kinetics (Fig. 14 c). The Ti3AlC2 substrate contributes excellent surface area and hydrophilicity, while Ce doping and selenization synergistically optimize electronic configurations through ligand field modulation. These combined effects endow the composite with superior bifunctional activity, demonstrating a 72-hour stability at 100 mA cm−2. This work advances the rational design of cost-effective electrocatalysts for industrial-scale water splitting. Liang et al. [130] employed a wet impregnation method to mix a certain ratio of Co(NO3)2∙6 H2O, Ammonium tetrathiomolybdate (ATTM) and Mo2CT x MXene, followed by vacuum drying and annealing under an argon gas flow to construct Co-MoS2/Mo2CT x nano heterostructures, achieving Co doping by partially substituting Mo atoms in MoS2. The Mo2CT x MXene functioned as both an electrochemically active and conductive substrate, significantly enhancing interfacial electron transport. Concurrently, Co doping strategically optimized the electronic configuration of MoS2, thereby enhancing the intrinsic catalytic activity. Rasool et al. [123] reported the synthesis of 1 T/2H-WS2 nanopetals intercalated between and over the Ti3C2T x (T x = F, Cl or OH) MXene layers via a one-step solvothermal method, forming a 2D-2D nanocomposite. Then pristine Ti3C2T x MXene was obtained through controlled HF etching with in situ acid generation to mitigate its corrosive effects. Microscopic analysis confirmed the integration of 1 T/2H-WS2 nanosheets (NSs) within the Ti3C2T x MXene matrix, establishing a robust 2D-2D heterointerface. The 5 % WS2-MXene composite exhibits exceptional HER activity, attributed to the synergistic coupling between WS2 nanopetals and Ti3C2T x MXene. This interfacial interaction not only enhances active site exposure but facilitates favorable electronic structure modulation. N-doped MXene based composite catalysts were successfully synthesized by introducing NC and highly dispersed Ru onto the MXene surface through the pyrolysis of RuCl3 coordinated with melamine and formaldehyde resin [146]. Controlled modulation of Ru nanoparticle (Ru NP) size and Ru single-atom (Ru SA) populations synergistically enhances HER performance through calcination temperature tuning. This synergistic enhancement originates from electronic structure optimization of Ru species, balancing the Ru NP-mediated H2O dissociation kinetics and Ru SA-dominated H2 desorption energetics. This methodology establishes a scalable paradigm for engineering composite catalysts, offering mechanistic insights into the rational design of high-efficiency Ru-based hydrogen evolution systems. Lv et al. [179] reported a method for converting Co2+ and H2PO2- into Co-P electrodes through a one-step electrodeposition process at room temperature, as well as a two-step electrodeposition process for the controlled growth of cobalt phosphides on MXene-modified NF followed by nitridation treatment. Co2P/N@Ti3C2T x @NF (denoted as CPN@TC) electrocatalyst with multiple heterostructure interfaces was prepared on the surface of 3D self-supported electrode (NF) modified with Ti3C2T x MXene. SEM and TEM analyses ( Fig. 15 a-g) confirm the uniform loading of MXene nanosheets on NF, followed by the homogeneous deposition of cobalt phosphides onto the MXene substrate, thereby forming a unique heterostructure. Charge redistribution and interfacial electron transfer across the multi-phase heterojunction significantly enhanced the electrocatalytic charge transfer kinetics, establishing an accelerated electron transport pathway. Electrochemical testing of the CPN@TC catalyst in 1 M KOH demonstrated exceptional HER performance, achieving an overpotential of 15 mV at 10 mA cm−2 and a Tafel slope of 30 mV dec−1 (Fig. 15 h, i). Ma et al. [189] synthesized a novel synergistic high-conductive MXene catalyst coupled with Ru/V co-doped CoP by a simple and effective electrodeposition and tube furnace phosphatization method, which in situ grew nano-arrays on the surface of carbon cloth ( Fig. 16 a). The hierarchically structured CoP catalyst, with its multi-component architecture, enhances catalytic reaction kinetics. The catalyst demonstrates the HER performance with overpotential of 30 mV and Tafel slope of 52.5 mV dec−1 at 10 mA cm−2, while maintaining 24 h stability at 100 mA cm−2 (Fig. 16 b, c). DFT simulations reveal that Ru/V co-doping synergizes with strong CoP-Ti3C2T x interfacial coupling to enhance the local electronic environment, precisely tuning adsorption energies of key intermediates (H*, OOH*). This dual doping and heterostructure engineering can induce d-band center downshifting (-0.35 eV vs. Fermi level), which thermodynamically facilitates intermediate adsorption-desorption equilibrium, thereby boosting bifunctional HER/OER activity. In summary, this work not only established a novel synthesis method for MXene-based bifunctional HER/OER electrocatalysts, but also proposed an effective strategy to enhance the electrocatalytic activity of phosphides. The approach offers a more efficient and environmentally sustainable pathway for hydrogen production via water splitting. As shown in Fig. 16 d, Ma et al. [137] synthesized a V-doped Co2P coupled with high-entropy MXene heterostructure catalyst of (TiVCrNbMo)5C4T x (V-Co2P@HE) through a two-step electrodeposition followed by controlled phosphorization. Through the analysis of SEM images, high-entropy MXene exhibit a typical accordion-like multi-layered morphology in Fig. 16 e, while the surfaces of V-Co-LDH and V-Co-LDH@HE have some nano-corals in Fig. 16 f and Fig. 16 g, which ‌enhance‌ the contact area between the catalyst ‌and‌ electrolyte. Strong electron interaction between high-entropy MXene and V-Co2P contributes to charge redistribution, improving the electrical conductivity and reducing charge transfer resistance. Furthermore, MXene’s surface hydrophilic groups (e.g., –OH) boost water molecule adsorption, accelerating the Volmer step (H2O dissociation). These results propose the innovative approaches for utilizing high-entropy MXene and developing non-noble metal-based MXene as the promising candidates of electrolytic water catalysts. 5 Conclusions and outlook The development of affordable and high-performance electrocatalysts is urgently required to commercialize these cutting-edge energy conversion technologies for HER. MXene has emerged as a greatly hopeful class of 2D materials for electrocatalysts due to the high conductivity, tunable surface chemistry and large specific surface area. This review contains the synthesis methods and current applications of MXene based electrocatalysts for HER. First, various synthesis routes for MXenes ‌include‌ chemical etching, molten salt etching, electrochemical etching, halogen-based etching and other novel methods. Notably, different synthesis conditions result in MXene products with ‌varied‌ surface chemistry and morphological characteristics. Furthermore, the review detailes the strategies to enhance the HER performance of MXenes, including surface functionalization, doping engineering ‌ and heterostructure construction‌. These strategies effectively modulate the electronic structure, increase active site density and enhance charge transfer kinetics. By implementing the aforementioned synthesis and modification strategies, the HER efficiency of MXene based electrocatalysts can be enhanced through the following approaches: (1) Current MXene production predominantly relies on hazardous fluorine-based etching methods, which impose severe limitations on manufacturing scalability and environmental compatibility. Future research should prioritize exploring diverse etching methodologies to develop environmentally friendly and cost-effective synthesis protocols. For example, molten salt etching in fluoride-free environments enables precise regulation of MXene morphology and surface termination groups, maintaining environmental benignity. Implementation of continuous manufacturing processes with automated control systems could revolutionize production scalability and cost-effectiveness. More importantly, developing flexible MXene based electrodes and designing biodegradable MXene derivatives can enable practical HER device implementation via structural and functional optimization. (2) MXene undergoes irreversible oxidation during electrocatalytic operation, subjected to its metallic conductivity and layered architecture. Furthermore, strong interfacial interactions between hydrophilic surface and aqueous electrolytes compromise long-term operational stability. To overcome these challenges, it is essential to optimize MAX phase precursor synthesis to achieve defect-minimized lattice deformation, enabling stable heterostructure construction, while implementing protective surface coatings during electrochemical testing to reduce harmful ion/molecule interactions. (3) The inherent high surface energy of MXene induces spontaneous nanosheet restacking during catalytic operation, which significantly diminishes accessible active sites. Current strategies involve rational material design with interfacial modification through composite engineering (e.g., rGO/MXene hybrids), 3D architectures (aerogels, foams) and tailored defect engineering. Complementary theoretical investigations should elucidate interlayer charge transfer mechanisms at atomic resolution, exploring advanced 3D framework configurations to suppress π-π stacking interactions. (4) Advanced first-principles methods combined with long timescale molecular dynamics can precisely simulate MXene-electrolyte interactions to determine electrocatalytic reactions, which may be favorable to identify active sites and elucidate reaction mechanisms. These multiscale approaches facilitate mechanistic unraveling of active site evolution and charge transfer kinetics at atomic dimension. Furthermore, recent advances in machine learning and artificial intelligence techniques have not only provided cost-effective alternatives through high-throughput material properties modeling, but also achieved superior HER efficiency among extensive electrocatalysts. These advancements will enable researchers to describe activity screening and determine systematic reaction mechanisms of electrocatalysts in the future. (5) Exploring the synthesis of electrochemical products such as chlorine, oxygen and nitrogen-based compounds can expand the applications and markets for electrocatalytic technology, while clean energy ecosystems may also be rapidly developed through research into alternative energy sources like solar-driven water splitting and sustainable power generation. Furthermore, interdisciplinary collaborations among experts and engineers in materials science, chemistry, physics and environmental science can propel innovation by integrating specialized knowledge to tackle complex, multifaceted challenges, accelerating the development of cost-effective and scalable industrial synthesis methods and HER efficiency of electrocatalysts. coredata.dc:description: The rapid growth of global urbanization and industrialization has aggravated environmental pollution and energy consumption. As a clean and renewable energy source, hydrogen has garnered significant attention for its potential in addressing these challenges. Note that MXenes, composed of transition metal carbides, nitrides or carbonitrides, are two-dimensional (2D) materials that have become attractive candidates for hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) process due to the high electrical conductivity, large surface area, excellent chemical stability and tunable surface chemical properties. This review provides a comprehensive overview of MXene based electrocatalysts for the HER, including various synthesis methods (chemical etching, physical etching, exfoliation and intercalation) and their effects on morphology, composition and electrochemical properties. The review further explores performance enhancement strategies including surface functionalization, doping engineering and heterostructure construction. Furthermore, it highlights current challenges and future prospects in MXene synthesis and applications in HER, while proposing a development framework for high-performance MXene based electrocatalysts in clean energy generation and energy conversion/storage systems.
